title: Moeaki Fotuaika
text:
Moeaki Fotuaika (born 16 November 1999) is a professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who plays as for the <a href="Gold%20Coast%20Titans">Gold Coast Titans</a> in the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">NRL</a>.
He has previously played at representative level for <a href="Queensland%20rugby%20league%20team">Queensland</a> in the <a href="State%20of%20Origin%20series">State of Origin series</a>.
Background.
Born in <a href="Gisborne%2C%20New%20Zealand">Gisborne, New Zealand</a>, Fotuaika moved to <a href="Brisbane">Brisbane</a> with his family in 2007 at age 7. 
He played his junior rugby league for the Greenbank Raiders and attended <a href="Keebra%20Park%20State%20High%20School">Keebra Park State High School</a> before being signed by the <a href="Gold%20Coast%20Titans">Gold Coast Titans</a>.
Playing career.
Early career.
In 2015, Fotuaika played for the <a href="Souths%20Logan%20Magpies">Souths Logan Magpies</a> in the <a href="Cyril%20Connell%20Cup">Cyril Connell Cup</a>. In 2016, he moved up to the club's <a href="Mal%20Meninga%20Cup">Mal Meninga Cup</a> side. In 2017, Fotuaika joined the <a href="Gold%20Coast%20Titans">Gold Coast Titans</a>, playing for their <a href="NRL%20Under-20s">under-20s</a> side, winning the club's Under-20 Player of the Year award. On 6 May 2017, Fotuaika represented the <a href="Junior%20Kiwis">Junior Kiwis</a> against the <a href="Junior%20Kangaroos">Junior Kangaroos</a>.
2018.
On 11 January, Fotuaika re-signed with the Titans until the end of the 2021 season, joining the club's NRL squad. He began the season playing for the <a href="Tweed%20Heads%20Seagulls">Tweed Heads Seagulls</a> in the <a href="Queensland%20Cup">Queensland Cup</a>.
In Round 9 of the <a href="2018%20NRL%20season">2018 NRL season</a>, he made his NRL debut in the Titans' 18–32 loss to the <a href="Canberra%20Raiders">Canberra Raiders</a>. He played 16 games in his rookie season for the club, scoring two tries. On 19 September, he was selected in the <a href="Tonga%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Tonga</a> 29-man squad for their Test match against <a href="Australian%20Kangaroos">Australia</a>, but did not play.
2019.
On 27 August, Fotuaika extended his contract with the Titans for one season, until the end of 2022. He played 21 games for the Titans before his season was cut short due to knee and wrist injuries.
On 13 September, Fotuaika won the Paul Broughton Medal for Titans' Player of the Year, becoming the youngest winner of the award.
2020.
On 7 October, Fotuaika was named in <a href="Queensland%20Maroons">Queensland</a>'s 27-man squad for the <a href="2020%20State%20of%20Origin%20series">2020 State of Origin series</a>, Fotuaika would debut in Origin 2 of the series off the bench in the 34–10 loss, however Queensland would end up winning the series 2–1.
2021.
He played 22 games for the Gold Coast in the <a href="2021%20NRL%20season">2021 NRL season</a> including the club's elimination final loss against the <a href="Sydney%20Roosters">Sydney Roosters</a>.
Personal life.
Fotuaika's older brother <a href="Mosese%20Fotuaika">Mosese</a>, who was a member of the <a href="Wests%20Tigers">Wests Tigers</a> NRL squad, committed suicide in 2013. Another older brother, <a href="Feao%20Fotuaika">Feao</a>, plays for the <a href="Queensland%20Reds">Queensland Reds</a> in <a href="Super%20Rugby">Super Rugby</a>.
